Award.AwardTitle: The emergence of cyberbullying from middle childhood through adolescence: A prospective latitudinal study

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although a considerable body of research has illuminated many aspects of school bullying, the problem persists and continues to garner much public and scholarly attention. Robust research findings can inform educators and lead to the development of effective prevention and intervention programs. A relative newcomer to the bullying arsenal is cyberbullying, the use of technology to harm or harass others. This form of bullying has proliferated quite rapidly, but the sparse research to date has been limited to considering prevalence rates, gender differences, and the relation of cyberbullying to traditional bullying. Although there are many similarities between the two forms of bullying, the distinctive features of cyberbullying may lead to unique consequences of victimization. Furthermore, the unique predictors of cyberbullying have not yet been identified. At this point, there is a need to understand early influences that serve as risk or protective factors for later involvement in cyberbullying. In this research project, Drs. Bauman and Card will investigate early influences suggested by modern social cognitive theory, which situates human behavior within a dynamic process of reciprocal interaction of the person, the environment, and the behavior. From this perspective, bullying and cyberbullying can be viewed as attempts by some individuals to control their environments to increase their social status. Other components of this theory describe how children learn behavior (including by vicarious observation), how cognitive processes such as attributional biases, moral disengagement, and contextual factors influence behaviors. This study will investigate the intrapersonal and environmental factors that predict cyberbullying involvement. It will also illuminate the trajectory of cyberbullying involvement from middle childhood to middle adolescence, when such behaviors tend to peak. By studying children, parents, and teachers over a three-year period, the investigators will be able to trace changes over time in the individual, the environment, and the behaviors.

This project will develop an understanding of how cyberbullying involvement emerges and how family and school environments affect the development of this behavior. It will illuminate how children's developing social cognitions interact with other factors to increase or decrease their vulnerability to cyberbullying involvement. This work is critical to developing a comprehensive and multi-dimensional understanding of this new and potentially damaging phenomenon. The findings from this investigation will provide a sound empirical basis for the development of effective prevention and intervention programs to reduce the prevalence and harmful consequences of cyberbullying.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Children report significantly different perceptions of the severity of cyberbullying, their teachers' knowledge about technology and their teachers understanding of cyberbullying than do teachers or parents. Significant differences were also found between what children say they would do in response to an incident of cyberbullying and what parents and teachers advise them to do. Few students reported that they would tell a teacher if they were cyberbullied. This suggests that new strategies for cyberbullying prevention and intervention are needed, and that educators need to demonstrate to youth that they are knowledgeable and can be helpful.

Sharing passwords among friends is a widespread behavior. We found that being involved in cyberbullying at year 1 (T1) of the study predicted decreased sharing of passwords at  year 2 (T2) , suggesting that youth realized the dangers of this practice from their experience. However, sharing passwords at year 1 was not associated with an increase in cyberbullying involvement at  year 2. In addition, using more social networking sites was associated with increased cyberbullying over time, suggesting that this platform is a platform in which cyberbullying occurs. Emphasis should be given to social networking use among youth, as it is a common venue for cyberbullying. Netiquette should be stressed in prevention programs.

Youth who reported  fewer beliefs to justify cyberbullying (e.g., if someone shares their password, they deserve to be cyberbullied" )  also reported less monitoring by parents of their online activities.  Youth who agreed with more statements to justify cyberbullying also reported  higher levels of   of traditional bullying. Cyberbullying involvement predicted increased traditional victimization and bullying, but was not associated with child or parent reports of parental monitoring.

The following factors were predictors of cyberbullying at the same time point:: having a Webkinz account (negative predictor), giving a friend your password, time spent on Facebook and the number of Facebook friends, being a cybervictim, moral disengagement (endorsing statements justifying cyberbullying), being a traditional bully, being a traditional victim, and child's view of parental monitoring, with the strongest predictor =  being a cybervictim.Predictors of cybervictimization were the child having a cell phone, being a cyberbullying (lstrongest predictor), being a traditional victim, being a traditional bully (negative predictor) and moral disengagement (thoughts justifying cyberbullying, which was a negative predictor.)

Longitudinal predictors of cyberbullying at year 2 were grade, number of Facebook friends, and year 1 moral disengagement, along with year 2 cyberbullying. Negative predictors of year 2 cyberbullying were T1 post to Youtube, T1 Webkinz account, and T1 time per day on Facebook. Significant longitudinal predictors of T2 cybervictimization were T2 cyberbullying, T1 involvement in Webkinz, T1 number of FB friends (negative) and T1 moral disengagement. That is, the strongest predictors of cyberbullying and cybervictimization at both time points were bring engaged in the other behavior. We identified fewer predictors of cybervictimization than of cyberbullying.
